Description: Pottery vessel of uncertain function, made of wet-smoothed red silt clay with frequent fine mica, abundant fine-medium grits and moderate medium-coarse lime inclusions. The convex sides descend from a bifid rim with internal ridge to a flattened base, slightly concave underneath. One side is perforated by a hole 1.4cm in diameter, made from the exterior before firing. Opposite this hole, on the interior wall is a triangular clay projection extending 3.5cm into the interior. Above the projection there is an indentation on the inner edge of the rim. About one fifth of the rim and a large portion of the side are missing.
Curator's comments: Very similar piece published from Naukratis, dated 7th to 5th century BC (Hogarth et. al. 1905, 125, fig. 5). Parallels also from Tell Dafana. Petrie (1886, 42) groups them with braziers.

Parallels from Tell Dafana, Petrie, W.M.F., Tanis II, Nebesheh and Defenneh, London, 1888, pl.xxxiv, no.26; Boston MFA 87.637. Other parallels: Petrie 1915, Hyksos and Israelite Cities, pl. x, no. 5; 1988, ‘Tell Fara’on-Imet’, BCE 13, 20–1, fig. 3
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (IB.039)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.103)
